turn.speaker: gregory_g_garre
turn.label: Mr. Gregory G. Garre
turn.text: --I think that that would create a factual issue and that that issue might well be tried, Justice Alito.
And the one thing that is important to keep in mind is that this is a request for injunctive relief and not damages.
So the only policy that matters -- and Wilkinson v. Austin makes this clear -- is the current policy; all parties agree that the current policy is the all-comers policy.
That's the policy supported by the record in this case.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I'm sorry.
All parties do not agree that the policy is the all-comers policy.
Your friend argued repeatedly that the policy was the written nondiscrimination policy.

turn.speaker: gregory_g_garre
turn.label: Mr. Gregory G. Garre
turn.text: I understood my friend's opening brief to acknowledge at the least that that's the policy the school has said it has today.
It is the school's policy.
It's supported by substantial history and sworn deposition testimony.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Garre, the -- the so-called written policy, that has a -- that list has a correspondence to the State's law, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: gregory_g_garre
turn.label: Mr. Gregory G. Garre
turn.text: It does.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: The categories that are listed there are the categories that under California law are proscribed bases for discrimination?

turn.speaker: gregory_g_garre
turn.label: Mr. Gregory G. Garre
turn.text: It does.
And that is an additional basis for the school's policy.
Look at California Education Code 66270.
It explicitly prohibits discrimination in -- in programs and educational activities by public schools like Hastings.
Hastings has an obligation under State law to prohibit discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.
The reason why we're here today is because CLS insisted on the right to discriminate, to exclude students on the basis of their sexual orientation.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Well, section 66270 applies to programs conducted by a post-secondary educational institution, and your position is that if -- if a religious group complies with your policies and then it conducts religious services, those religious services are conducted by Hastings?

turn.speaker: gregory_g_garre
turn.label: Mr. Gregory G. Garre
turn.text: Our position is that the registered student organization program is a program of the university; it's subsidized by the university; it's recognized by the university; and that all students should be able to enjoy access to that program.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: In your response to Justice Ginsburg concerning California law, is it your position that California law requires religious groups to admit people who do not believe in their religious beliefs and in fact to conduct services of that group?

turn.speaker: gregory_g_garre
turn.label: Mr. Gregory G. Garre
turn.text: Your Honor, our position is that the provision that we've cited to, 66270, does not carve out an exemption in this program for a religious student organization.
On its face--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: So the answer to my question is "yes"?

turn.speaker: gregory_g_garre
turn.label: Mr. Gregory G. Garre
turn.text: --Yes.
On its face, it excludes -- it has an exemption for religious schools; it does not include an exemption for religious organizations within the context of this program.
And we think that the program is reasonable.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Garre.

turn.speaker: gregory_g_garre
turn.label: Mr. Gregory G. Garre
turn.text: Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. McConnell, you have 4 minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: michael_w_mcconnell
turn.label: Mr. Michael W. McConnell
turn.text: Well, thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.
First, in answer to Justice Stevens' question, we do believe that the Court needs to reach the constitutionality of the all-comers policy as applied to CLS in this case.
We brought only an as-applied challenge.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Put -- put to a side a moment -- forget the as-applied.
Just take a -- a pure all-comers policy.
Must we decide the constitutionality of that?

turn.speaker: michael_w_mcconnell
turn.label: Mr. Michael W. McConnell
turn.text: Not facially, but as applied to CLS, yes.
Several other points, I know--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Could you talk about -- I had understood from your brief that CLS did not have a -- a policy of excluding people with homosexual disposition, but that it was only homosexual conduct.

turn.speaker: michael_w_mcconnell
turn.label: Mr. Michael W. McConnell
turn.text: --That's correct as stipulated to, undisputed.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, you -- but your complaint said otherwise.
Your -- your--

turn.speaker: michael_w_mcconnell
turn.label: Mr. Michael W. McConnell
turn.text: That's -- that's because we -- the complaint is accepting the -- Hastings' definition of sexual orientation.
We were told that our conduct rule, our nonmarital conduct rule, violated their sexual orientation provision, and therefore we sought relief from their sexual orientation provision.
It was nothing more than that.
There -- it is -- it is stipulated in Joint Stipulation 40, I believe it is, that -- that CLS's rule is based on conduct--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Oh, okay.

turn.speaker: michael_w_mcconnell
turn.label: Mr. Michael W. McConnell
turn.text: --not orientation.
Several other points: My friend twice in his presentation stated that the all-comers policy is simply their way of implementing the nondiscrimination policy.
But if so, it is so absurdly overbroad as to be unconstitutional.
There is no reason to stop the environmentalist club from leading -- from requiring its leaders to share environmentalist views--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. McConnell--

turn.speaker: michael_w_mcconnell
turn.label: Mr. Michael W. McConnell
turn.text: --in order to--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Mr. McConnell, you don't challenge that there are universities, including four law schools, that have an all-comers policy?

turn.speaker: michael_w_mcconnell
turn.label: Mr. Michael W. McConnell
turn.text: --So far as we've been able to tell, there is no public university law school in the country that has such a policy.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: There are private universities.

turn.speaker: michael_w_mcconnell
turn.label: Mr. Michael W. McConnell
turn.text: There are some private universities that, according to the AALS, have such a policy.
We know nothing about them.
They are not in the record, and, frankly, I'd be a little bit surprised, because the policy is so absurd.
Think of how it would apply to the law school itself, and this policy does apply to the law school itself.
Does Hastings really mean to say it is committing itself to an all-comers policy when it hires faculty or admits students?
Do they not care about the belief of its dean of admissions, about beliefs of -- about, say, affirmative action?
The very idea of it is preposterous.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: It's not totally, if -- but it's imaginary, it's fantastical.
The -- you could imagine a school in the '60s that said that we think the way to advance learning is everyone gets together in a nice discussion group and hugs each other and talks, all right?
[Laughter]
Now, that's a possible educational theory.

turn.speaker: michael_w_mcconnell
turn.label: Mr. Michael W. McConnell
turn.text: It's possible, but--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: They say that we are going to apply that to everybody because that's how we do it.
And--

turn.speaker: michael_w_mcconnell
turn.label: Mr. Michael W. McConnell
turn.text: --Yes, but Hastings has--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --if there are any ideological organizations that suffer--

turn.speaker: michael_w_mcconnell
turn.label: Mr. Michael W. McConnell
turn.text: --But Hastings has--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --so be it, but it's fantastical, and therefore--

turn.speaker: michael_w_mcconnell
turn.label: Mr. Michael W. McConnell
turn.text: --Hastings has a perfectly conventional RSO program just like the ones in Healy, and Widmar and Rosenberger.
They just have a policy that is destructive of that--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --Well, my--

turn.speaker: michael_w_mcconnell
turn.label: Mr. Michael W. McConnell
turn.text: --of that program.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --my question is, if I can think of this policy -- but I tend to sympathize with your view that it's so hard to believe that they really hold it, maybe they do, I don't know about it -- what do I do with this case?
How can I say whether this, let's call it "hug your neighbor policy" is -- to put a label on it that's catchy--

turn.speaker: michael_w_mcconnell
turn.label: Mr. Michael W. McConnell
turn.text: What can--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --how do I -- how do I evaluate that?

turn.speaker: michael_w_mcconnell
turn.label: Mr. Michael W. McConnell
turn.text: --What you can say is that Healy v. James requires a substantial justification for exclusion of a student group from a registered student activity forum, and this is not a substantial justification; it is a silly justification.
If it is silly, crazy, and preposterous, it is not even reasonable, let alone compelling or substantial.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. McConnell.
The case is submitted.
